Task Name: Investigate distributed Cluster config/be able to update cluster config during business days.
Task Content:
What should we do?
Have distributed Cluster config, so that the config can be updated while the Cluster is running.
Why should we do it?
With this we could tune the available capacity during business days, as well as we could even develop a tool that would do this automatically, by processing usage stats and changing the config.
More details
The only thing we really care about changing in production is the limits/capacity configs. We'd like to increase/decrease the max and idle counts of clusters and pools without having to reboot or deploy a new cluster.

Task Name: Migrate tags to postgres arrays III.
Task Content:
What should we do?
Modify the code to stop filling up the string tags fields.
Drop the string app fields from all the modified tables.
Why should we do it?
Since we decided (at least I think we decided) we're only going to support posgresql as the DEN db we should migrate the string tags to postgres arrays which are more convenient for this purpose. Currently they're stored in a varchar(255) which has length and indexing limitations. Migrate to arrays of varchar(255) fields.

Migration needs to be applied in multiple places where tags are stored (e. g. tasks, intro secrets). Modify the code accordingly (for example the task-agent matcher function).
More details

Task Content:
Use case(s)
Using this library the development of the DEN CLI would be much cleaner, and consistent with the Cobra & Viper idiom (which should be practiced across all of Infra's major command line tools)
Description
Right now the DEN CLI does not utilise the Viper library (opposed to most of DEN), but uses our envutil package, and the server's configuration package for fetching environment variables, which is a bit messy.
Additional resources/research (optional)
The configuration right now mostly happens at the root.go file
https://github.com/bitrise-team/den/blob/master/cli/cmd/root.go

This behaviour should be implemented in a separate config function which loads the necessary defaults, an optional config file, the environment, and the Cobra flags into Viper. This function then should setup in Cobra's OnInitialize (in main.go) function, so it would be called before every method's Execute call. Then every method could query Viper for correct configuration values safely.

Task Name: Encrypt Task data (including the configs and secrets, which includes SSH key) before storing into DB.
Task Content:
Use case(s)
Secrets should not be stored unencrypted in our DEN (Server) DB.
Description
Current flow is:
A Task is created via the API
DEN Server stores the Task config (including secrets) into it's Postgres DB
When Agent asks for a Task the DEN server will read the Task data from DB and give it to the Agent.

Changed flow:
A Task is created via the API (same as it is today)
DEN Server **encrypts** the task data (config, secrets) and stores the **encrypted** data in the PostgresDB
When the Agent asks for a Task the DEN server will read the **encrypted** Task config/data from the DB, **decrypt** it and give it to the Agent (in non encrypted form).

How it should work for the user
We should store secret information in the DEN DB in an encrypted form, so that if someone gains access to the DB or to a backup/DB dump these information would be encrypted inside it. 

Additional resources / research (optional)
Use the same Symmetric encryption we use in the Website for storing sensitive data encrypted in the DB: aes-256-gcm - https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-website/blob/master/app/models/repository.rb#L94

Task Name: setup protected branch approved by code owners
Research whether increasing build machine GCE disk size to 200GB improves performance
Task Content:
Use case(s)
When creating a VM via gcloud we see this warning: WARNING: You have selected a disk size of under [200GB]. This may result in poor I/O performance. For more information, see: https://developers.google.com/compute/docs/disks#performance. 
Description
Evaluate whether increasing disk size increases performance.

It costs ~$4/mo/VM to do this, so we should measure whether this actually has any noticeable performance increase. 

How it should work for the user
Better performance.

Key Results that need to be tracked
Better performance. We should run a baseline test to check performance currently and then run a series of comparisons with increased disk size

Blog post if it actually makes a difference - it's important to make our users see that we do tune the infra for them - money well spent with us.

Additional resources / research (optional)

Task Name: Create a suite of test projects for the VM updates and a checker script/workflow that ensures no sample failed
Task Content:
Use case
Be able to quickly and efficiently run & check the sample/test builds on the updated VMs during the weekly VM update procedure (and also run control builds on them every day, to detect mid-week regressions, which aren't infra related).
What to do
Create github.com/bitrise-io/testman repo as a **private** repository (private because we'll have to use private API params for non published VM stacks)
Create a new Bitrise.io Organization with the name Regression Test Projects
Invite the Infra & Tooling teams as well as Viktor
Set the build timeout of the org to 10800 (3 hours)
Grant 5 concurrencies to the org
Move our existing samples we use for the weekly VM update regression checks into this org
testman should include the test runner tool + a testman-config.yml 
Register the testman repo on Bitrise into this Regression Tests org
Create scheduled builds for every day which runs testman on the current PROD stacks
Create a workflow which runs testman on the "beta"/"upcoming" stacks, which aren't available for users - will be triggered as part of the VM updates process.
In all workflows have a Slack step that notifies us if it would fail.
Once ready delete the old script based solution we used
https://github.com/bitrise-team/system-tests
https://app.bitrise.io/app/bac1fe9669707858#/builds

Testman:
Requires a Personal Access Token (as env var or flag)
When you run testman:
It should trigger all the test builds defined in testman-config.yml 
Wait for the results
Should succeed if non fails, should fail if at least one fails (non success, including error or abort)
Be able to re-run a single test (in case we'd have to re run one or a few, but not all)

testman-config.yml:

stacks:
    - xcode-9.4.x
    - xcode-10.0.x
    - ...
apps: [
    {
        slug: asdf1234,
        description: "android-sdk22 runs Emulator test",
        branches: [master]
        workflows: [primary]
        stacks:
        - xcode-9.4.0x
        - ...
    }
]



Additional resources/research (optional)
For "Full VM test" we use https://app.bitrise.io/app/bac1fe9669707858#/builds /https://github.com/bitrise-team/system-tests right now, though this is most likely an overkill to run on every single stack, but we should come up with just the minimum amount of samples we care about, with tests for most of the popular tools (e.g. cocoapods/ruby based tool - this is missing from the current single VM update sample project build we perform).
Checklists: {"Creator Checklist":["I've added at least one use case","I've proposed how it should work for the user (user journey)","I've proposed a priority"]}

Task Name: Create "validate" command for Cluster and run that on the configs inside bitrise-control-provision
Task Content:
What should we do?
Create a validate command in Cluster to be able to run it on cluster configs. Then wire it in for validation of cluster configs in https://github.com/bitrise-io/build-control-provision  repo.
Why should we do it?
To prevent issues like https://github.com/bitrise-io/build-control-provision/pull/90/commits/b6444a108dd73eeb54efc6db095af0bf51ad88be#diff-fa466daaab8a5c67202cf4705e2277d7R77 ( discussion: https://bitfall.slack.com/archives/C9VFETHDW/p1556983488081000 ).

Basically because of the indent issue there were 0 pools defined in the YAML. Instead of:

pools:
  '--osx-xcode-edge#--elite1#--mac-stadium#--green':
It was
pools:
'--osx-xcode-edge#--elite1#--mac-stadium#--green':
. When deployed into production the cluster gave an error, but we only got that in production because of the lack of config validation.
More details
The validate command should use the exact same validation function the Cluster has when it starts & validates its config.

Task Content:
What should we do?
Find a vSphere consultant (person or company) who can help us with tweaking/fine-tuning our MacStadium vSphere configs.

Goal of this card:
Find a few(3+) potential candidates
Contact them
Have a quote/hourly $ from them to see how much they charge for helping us with the config review & tweaks.
Collect the infos in a doc that we can then review and decide which one to choose.
Why should we do it?
We lack the required deeper knowledge about vSphere to be able to find the right vSphere config that helps us with the queues.

We'd also like to contact the consultant in the future as we had quite a few cases in the past where someone with more vSphere knowledge would probably be able to help resolve a specific issue or fine-tuning faster than we can.
More details
This site was suggested on YC internal forum: https://www.vmug.com/home
The Hungarian sub community: https://community.vmug.com/communities/localcommunityhome?CommunityKey=da657737-6fc8-44e4-a785-4678c6c4a1b6 - might worth to ask for recommendation here

Another option might be proservices Kft who we contacted about the office network maintenance, they are a VMware certified partner.

What should we do?
Please write a postmortem in https://bitrise.pagerduty.com/postmortems about #incident-20190307-2 
Why should we do it?
A post-mortem (or postmortem) is a process intended to help you learn from past incidents. It typically involves an analysis or discussion soon after an event has taken place.

As your systems scale and become more complex, failure is inevitable, assessment and remediation is more involved and time-consuming, and it becomes increasingly painful to repeat recurring mistakes. Not having data when you need it is expensive.

The good news is, most organizations do have some kind of a post-mortem process in place to assess what happened once a service has been restored. Arguably, any resolution of an issue isnt truly complete until a team has fully documented and reflected on it.

(https://www.pagerduty.com/resources/learn/post-mortem-incident-report/)
More details
PagerDuty's postmortem feature is really neat, it guides you through the right things to collect, for smaller incidents it usually takes less than 30 minutes to collect all the data that will help us improve.

What should we do?
Help the team's workdays with the listed tasks: https://app.nuclino.com/Bitrise/Infrastructure/Facilitator-of-the-Week-ffb0c876-fb5c-4ce9-9c34-39ce29b3a5f8
Why should we do it?
This way other team members do not need to care about administrative tasks, they can be more focused during the week.

Task Content:
Use case(s)
Be able to manage dnsimple.com our DNS service via code (and PR reviews), instead of via the UI.
How it should work for the user
If anyone needs a DNS change the person should just create a PR in the dnsimple-terraform repository, and once approved that change will be applied automatically.

For this we would use terraform and its dnsimple provider https://www.terraform.io/docs/providers/dnsimple/index.html so that we just have a repository and a related bitrise.io app which applies that dnsimple terraform config.
Additional resources/research (optional)
https://www.terraform.io/docs/providers/dnsimple/index.html
